profileText: A Delegate from the Territory of Utah; born in Cambridge, Dorchester County, Md., December 25, 1813; attended the common schools; engaged in mercantile pursuits; moved to Illinois in 1835 and settled in Galena; engaged in trade on the Mississippi River; moved to Utah in 1850 and settled in Salt Lake City; secretary of the Territory in 1857 and 1858; elected as a Democrat to the Thirty-sixth Congress (March 4, 1859-March 3, 1861); unsuccessful candidate for reelection in 1860 to the Thirty-seventh Congress; member of the State senate in 1862; elected to the Thirty-ninth and to the three succeeding Congresses (March 4, 1865-March 3, 1873); was not a candidate for renomination in 1872; engaged in mercantile pursuits and mining operations in Salt Lake City; superintendent of Zion's Cooperative Mercantile Institution 1873-1877, and its president 1877-1882; president of the Deseret National Bank, Salt Lake City, from 1872 until his death in Salt Lake City, Utah, December 30, 1882; interment in Salt Lake City Cemetery.

note.content: Election unsuccessfully contested by William McGrorty.

researchRecord.name: 1857, 1 item.
researchRecord.description: A letter from Elisha Whistling to Lewis Cass written on March 21, 1857. In the letter, Elisha Whistling writes about a request of William H. Hooper, Secretary of the Utah Territory, regarding requisitions for 1857.

researchRecord.name: 1856, 1 volume.
researchRecord.description: A resolution signed by Brigham Young and W. H. Hooper regarding that the seat of government in Utah should be moved from Fillmore to Salt Lake City due to a lack of facilities in Fillmore.

researchRecord.name: 1861, 1 item,
researchRecord.description: A letter from W. H. Hooper to Colonel Thomas W. Ellerbeck written on March 21, 1861. In the letter, W. H. Hooper writes about the possibility of sending arms to Utah and of arming emigrants coming to Utah.

researchRecord.name: 1856, 1 item.
researchRecord.description: A letter from W. H. Hooper to the Honorable E. Smith, Probate Judge for Great Salt Lake Company. In the letter, W. H. Hooper states that he is submitting an inventory of the estate of the late Almon Whiting Babbitt.

researchRecord.name: 1882-1883, 2 items.
researchRecord.description: Photocopies of correspondence which include information on the death of William Henry Hooper.

researchRecord.name: In the W. Medieo Papers, 1857, 2 letters.
researchRecord.description: A letter from W. Medieo to William H. Hooper relates to W. H. Hooper's application to be the acting "Secretary Pro tem" of Utah.

researchRecord.name: In the Salt Lake City, Utah Recorder's Office Records, 1852-1859, 4 pages.
researchRecord.description: The papers include documentation of the sale of a slave named Dan to William H. Hooper.

researchRecord.name: In the Brigham Young Papers, ca. 1859-1867, 64 items.
researchRecord.description: Includes letters from Brigham Young to William Henry Hooper about legislation concerning Utah, such as polygamy and statehood. The letters also mention local affairs and irrigation in Utah, the overland mail, Pony Express, telegraph, gold discoveries, Indians, and family and church news.

recordLocation.name: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

researchRecord.name: 1869, 14 pages.
researchRecord.description: A speech by the Honorable W. H. Hooper of Utah delivered in the House of Representatives on February 25, 1869.

researchRecord.name: 1873, 16 pages.
researchRecord.description: A speech titled Vindication of the people of Utah given by William H. Hooper of Utah in the House of Representatives on January 29, 1873. The speech was in reply to the charges of Honorable W. H. Clagett of Montana on January 28th and 29th, 1873.

researchRecord.name: 1870, 40 pages.
researchRecord.description: A speech by the Honorable W. H. Hooper of Utah delivered in the House of Representatives on March 23, 1970 on the Utah Bill: a plea for religious liberty. The speech was given with the remonstrance of the citizens of Salt Lake City, in a mass meeting held on March 31, 1870 to the Senate of the United States.

researchRecord.name: 1867, 21 pages.
researchRecord.description: Papers in the case of McGrorty vs. Hooper, delegate from the Territory of Utah.

researchRecord.name: n.d., 23 pages.
researchRecord.description: Consists of biographical essays written by William Henry Hooper. The essays include a transcript of a speech against the Cullom Bill.

researchRecord.name: In the Joseph Johnson Imlay Papers, 1859, 3 pages.
researchRecord.description: A power of attorney from Joseph Johnson Imlay to William Hopper.
